title: Atomic Kitten
text:
{{short description|British girl group}}
{{Use British English|date=December 2012}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2021}}
{{Infobox musical artist
| name             = Atomic Kitten
| image            = Atomic_Kitten_in_concert.jpg
| image_upright    = 
| caption          = Atomic Kitten on 28 August 2005. From left to right: Liz McClarnon, Jenny Frost, and Natasha Hamilton
| origin           = [[Liverpool]], England
| genre            = {{hlist|[[Pop music|Pop]]|[[dance-pop]]|[[Europop]]|[[disco]]}}
| years_active     = {{Flatlist|
* 1998–2004
* 2013–present<!-- Official comeback on 31 January 2013 at The Big Reunion premiere -->
}}
| label            = {{hlist|[[Columbia Records|Columbia]]|[[EMI]]|[[Innocent Records|Innocent]]|[[Virgin Records|Virgin]]}}
| associated_acts  = {{hlist|[[Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark|OMD]]|[[Precious (band)|Precious]]|[[Sugababes]]}}
| website          = {{URL|atomickitten.com}}
| current_members  = * [[Jenny Frost]]
* [[Liz McClarnon]]
* [[Natasha Hamilton]]
| past_members     = * [[Kerry Katona]]
* [[Heidi Range]]
| alias            = <!-- Do not add "Automatic Kitten" here; the documentation at template:Infobox musical artist says "For listing official stage names for the act or solo artist" (i.e. not former names) -->
| landscape        = yes
}}
'''Atomic Kitten''' is an [[England|English]] [[girl group]] formed in [[Liverpool]] in 1998, whose current members are [[Liz McClarnon]], [[Jenny Frost]] and [[Natasha Hamilton]]. The group was founded by [[Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark]] (OMD) members [[Andy McCluskey]] and [[Stuart Kershaw]], who served as principal songwriters during Atomic Kitten's early years. The group's debut album ''[[Right Now (Atomic Kitten album)|Right Now]]'' was released in October 2000 and charted at number 39 in the United Kingdom. After five top ten singles, original member [[Kerry Katona]] quit – four weeks before "[[Whole Again]]" reached number one in the UK Singles Chart – and was replaced by former [[Precious (band)|Precious]] singer Jenny Frost. "Whole Again" became the group's most successful single, staying at number one for four weeks in the UK and six weeks in Germany, and reaching number one in many other territories; in Britain, it was the 13th best-selling single of the 2000s.{{citation needed|date=March 2022}} The group re-released their debut album, with some tracks re-recorded with Frost's vocals: it peaked at number one in the UK and was certified double platinum after selling over 600,000 copies.

Between 2002 and 2004, the group released a further two studio albums, ''[[Feels So Good (Atomic Kitten album)|Feels So Good]]'' (which also went double platinum in the UK) and ''[[Ladies Night (Atomic Kitten album)|Ladies Night]]'', and a greatest hits album before announcing a break following their 2004 tour.<ref name="uk"/><ref name="bpi">{{cite web |url=http://www.bpi.co.uk/certifiedawards/search.aspx |title=BPI Certified Awards |publisher=[[British Phonographic Industry]] |access-date=4 September 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/5mr0Evm3j?url=http://www.bpi.co.uk/certifiedawards/search.aspx |archive-date=17 January 2010}}</ref> To date the group have had three UK number-one singles: "[[Whole Again]]", the fourth-best-selling song of all time by a girl group in the UK; "[[Eternal Flame (song)|Eternal Flame]]", a song originally recorded by [[The Bangles]]; and "[[The Tide Is High (Get the Feeling)]]", a song originally recorded by [[The Paragons]].<ref name="uk">{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/artist/_/atomic%20kitten/|title=UK Charts > Atomic Kitten|publisher=[[Official Charts Company]]|access-date=27 July 2010}}</ref> They have sold over 10 million records worldwide.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.lep.co.uk/what-s-on/music/nothing-going-on-but-the-rent-for-atomic-kitten-star-natasha-hamilton-1-6227282 |title= Nothing going on but the Rent for Atomic Kitten star Natasha Hamilton |work= [[Lancashire Evening Post]] |publisher= [[Johnston Press]] |date= 11 March 2014 |access-date= 12 March 2014 |archive-date= 18 November 2013 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20131118161117/http://www.lep.co.uk/what-s-on/music/nothing-going-on-but-the-rent-for-atomic-kitten-star-natasha-hamilton-1-6227282 |url-status= dead }}</ref>

After making sporadic appearances from 2005 to 2008, it was announced that McClarnon, Hamilton, and Katona would reunite for the [[ITV2]] series ''[[The Big Reunion]]'', alongside five other pop groups of their time: [[B*Witched]], [[Five (band)|Five]], [[Liberty X]], [[Honeyz]] and [[911 (UK band)|911]].<ref name="The Big Reunion"/> Frost was unable to take part in the comeback because of her pregnancy.<ref name="Jenny Frost">{{cite news |url= http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a469327/atomic-kittens-natasha-hamilton-jenny-frost-could-return.html|title=Atomic Kitten's Natasha Hamilton: 'Jenny Frost has could return' |publisher=Digital Spy |date=28 March 2013 |access-date=29 March 2013 }}</ref> Katona left the group for a second time in December 2017 leaving the group as a duo until Frost returned to the group in 2021.

==History==

===1998–2001: Formation, ''Right Now'' and Katona's first departure===
[[File:Andy McCluskey.JPG|thumb|right|Atomic Kitten co-founder [[Andy McCluskey]] performing with [[Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark|OMD]] in 2011]]
Atomic Kitten was first conceived in 1998 by English musician [[Andy McCluskey]], best known as the frontman of [[New wave music|new wave]] group [[Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark]] (OMD). [[Karl Bartos]] of [[Kraftwerk]] suggested he create a new band as a vehicle for his songs following the 1996 dissolution of OMD,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandpopfeatures/7991217/OMD-Orchestral-manoeuvres-in-the-Noughties.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220112/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandpopfeatures/7991217/OMD-Orchestral-manoeuvres-in-the-Noughties.html |archive-date=12 January 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live|title=OMD: Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Noughties|last=McCormick|first=Neil|date=9 September 2010|website=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]]|access-date=5 October 2013}}{{cbignore}}</ref> who had been rendered unfashionable by the prevalence of [[grunge]] and [[indie rock]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.miaminewtimes.com/music/things-to-do-miami-orchestral-manoeuvres-in-the-dark-at-broward-center-for-the-performing-arts-august-27-2019-11252961|title=Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark Pioneered Millennial Pop Music|last=Cárdenas|first=Patricia|date=27 August 2019|website=[[Miami New Times]]|access-date=25 March 2022}}</ref><ref name="bbcbreakfast">{{cite episode|title=OMD|series=[[BBC Breakfast]]|network=[[BBC One]]|station=[[BBC|British Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=13 September 2010|quote=I left the music industry kicking and screaming in terms of performing, because at the height of indie rock and Britpop, [OMD] were totally out of fashion. I was conceited enough to think I could still write songs, and went and put [Atomic Kitten together] [...] It's very dirty, lots of backstabbing... it's a very strange world, the manufactured pop industry.}}</ref> McCluskey founded Atomic Kitten alongside fellow OMD member [[Stuart Kershaw]], and the pair would serve as principal songwriters on the group's studio recordings in the late 1990s and early 2000s.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2001/nov/23/artsfeatures2|title=The power behind pop|last=Petridis|first=Alexis|author-link=Alexis Petridis|date=23 November 2001|website=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=9 September 2017}}</ref>

The lineup initially featured [[Liz McClarnon]], [[Kerry Katona]], and [[Heidi Range]], but did not have a name. In her autobiography ''Too Much, Too Young: My Story of Love, Survival and Celebrity'', Katona mentions that they pondered names such as Exit and Honeyheads, before settling on Automatic Kitten, the name of a fashion label owned by designer Mary Lamb.<ref name="too much too young">{{cite book|last=Katona|first=Kerry|date=5 October 2006|title=Too Much, Too Young: My Story of Love, Survival and Celebrity|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sWTa1hx6rCUC&q=%22Automatic+Kitten%22+atomic&pg=PA161|location=London|publisher=[[Ebury Publishing]]|pages=161–162|isbn=978-0-09-191390-8|author-link=Kerry Katona}}</ref> When Katona went home to tell her mother about the band, her mother's friend was unable to pronounce "Automatic Kitten" and kept saying "Atomic Kitten". Katona liked the name and told her bandmates about it; they all felt the same way and the name stuck.<ref name="too much too young" /> Range later quit after being offered a different record deal,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kmDgXKZpZos |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/kmDgXKZpZos |archive-date=21 December 2021 |url-status=live|title=Heidi Range on Atomic Kitten & joining/the end of Sugababes (Ladies Of Liverpool, UK, June 2020)|publisher=YouTube|date=16 August 2020|access-date=16 August 2020}}{{cbignore}}</ref> and was replaced by [[Natasha Hamilton]]. Range went on to have success with another girl group, the [[Sugababes]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/showbiz/10-things-about/news/a459660/ten-things-about-atomic-kitten/|title=Ten Things About... Atomic Kitten|last=Earp|first=Catherine|date=22 February 2013|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|access-date=17 April 2017}}</ref>

The group's debut single, "[[Right Now (Atomic Kitten song)|Right Now]]", was released in late November 1999 and reached number ten on the [[UK Singles Chart]]. "[[See Ya (Atomic Kitten song)|See Ya]]" followed in March 2000 and reached number six.<ref name="uk" /> Following this initial success, Atomic Kitten performed an Asian tour and achieved their first number-one hit in Asia with "Cradle". In 2000 they recorded a cover of "[[The Loco-Motion|The Locomotion]]" for the movie ''[[Thomas and the Magic Railroad]]''. The album, also titled ''[[Right Now (Atomic Kitten album)|Right Now]]'', was first released in Japan on 16 March 2000 and released in the United Kingdom on 23 October 2000 following the release of two further singles, "[[I Want Your Love (Atomic Kitten song)|I Want Your Love]]" and "[[Follow Me (Atomic Kitten song)|Follow Me]]", with a slightly modified tracklist. The album's Japanese edition included a rare remix of "Cradle", an early version of "I Want Your Love" titled "All The Right Things", the original version of "Whole Again", which has only Kerry Katona speaking all the verses in the song, while Natasha Hamilton and Liz McClarnon sing the chorus, and a remix of "Right Now".

In Europe, the album was unsuccessful upon its first release, peaking at number 39 on the [[UK Albums Chart]].<ref name="uk" /> There were no initial plans to focus on the global market and Atomic Kitten's label, [[Innocent Records]], was even considering dropping them because of their limited success. However, the record company was persuaded to let the group release one more single from the album.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/music/2538381.stm|title=Atomic Kitten's perfect year|work=BBC News|date=30 December 2002|access-date=9 July 2006}}</ref> That single, "[[Whole Again]]", became their first number-one hit in the United Kingdom and stayed at the top for four consecutive weeks.<ref name="uk" /> Due to this success, "Whole Again" was released globally, and reached number one in 18 other countries, including 6 weeks in Germany and New Zealand.<ref name="gersing">{{cite web|url=http://www.musicline.de/de/chartverfolgung_summary/artist/Atomic+Kitten/single?sort=entry|title=Chartverfolgung / Atomic Kitten / Single|language=de|publisher=musicline.de PhonoNet|access-date=29 July 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121009135826/http://www.musicline.de/de/chartverfolgung_summary/artist/Atomic+Kitten/single?sort=entry|archive-date=9 October 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref> The song and video for "Whole Again" originally featured Kerry Katona (her vocals were also in "Hippy" and "Get Real"), but several days before the single's release, she left because of her pregnancy.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1742999.stm BBC News: McFadden and Katona tie knot]. Retrieved 30 July 2006</ref> Former [[Precious (band)|Precious]] singer Jenny Frost replaced her in the line-up and the single's music video was re-shot; a US video for "Whole Again" was also released. The Katona-Frost switch led to the decision to partially re-record and re-release the ''Right Now'' album which then went to number one in the UK in August 2001, and was certified double Platinum.<ref name="uk" /><ref name="bpi" /> The album also reached the Top 10 in several European countries, including Germany and Denmark.<ref name="geralb">{{cite web|url=http://www.musicline.de/de/chartverfolgung_summary/artist/ATOMIC+KITTEN/?type=longplay|title=Chartverfolgung / Atomic Kitten / Longplay|language=de|publisher=musicline.de PhonoNet|access-date=27 July 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121009142033/http://www.musicline.de/de/chartverfolgung_summary/artist/ATOMIC+KITTEN/?type=longplay|archive-date=9 October 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name="den">{{cite web|url=https://danishcharts.dk/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Atomic+Kitten |title=Danish Charts > Atomic Kitten |publisher=danishcharts.dk Hung Medien |access-date=27 July 2010}}</ref> Atomic Kitten's first album was repackaged with 3 brand-new tracks: "Eternal Flame", "Tomorrow & Tonight", and "You Are", and includes vocals from Jenny Frost in "Right Now", "Whole Again", "Hippy", and remixed versions of "Bye Now" and "Cradle".

Their next single, "[[Eternal Flame (Atomic Kitten song)|Eternal Flame]]", a cover of [[the Bangles]]' 1989 hit, became their second number-one single in the UK and New Zealand and is featured in the film ''[[The Parole Officer]]'' and the ''[[So Far So Good (DVD)|So Far So Good]]'' DVD.<ref name=uk/><ref name=nz>{{cite web|url=https://charts.nz/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Atomic+Kitten|title=New Zealand Charts > Atomic Kitten|publisher=charts.nz|access-date=24 July 2008}}</ref> It became their biggest single in France—peaking at number two—and eventually went Gold. In late 2001, the band announced they would be releasing a final single from the repackaged album, "[[You Are (Atomic Kitten song)|You Are]]". A video was recorded and promo singles were sent out to radio, but the single was ultimately shelved, never getting a full commercial release.<ref name=fra>{{cite web|url=http://lescharts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Atomic+Kitten|title=French Charts > Atomic Kitten|language=fr|publisher=lescharts.com Hung Medien|access-date=27 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.disqueenfrance.com/fr/page-259165.xml?year=2002&type=7 |title=Disque en France > Certifications Singles > Or > 2002 |publisher=[[Syndicat National de l'Édition Phonographique]] |access-date=28 July 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110710135500/http://www.disqueenfrance.com/fr/page-259165.xml?year=2002&type=7 |archive-date=10 July 2011}}</ref> That same year, "Right Now" was featured in [[Konami]]'s hit arcade videogame, ''[[DDR 5th Mix|Dance Dance Revolution 5th MIX]]''.

===2002–2003: New lineup, ''Feels So Good'' and international breakthrough===
Following the success of ''Right Now'', a new album, ''[[Feels So Good (Atomic Kitten album)|Feels So Good]]'', was recorded. The songwriting and production agreement with Andy McCluskey and Stuart Kershaw was an increasing source of tension within the group, and the pair departed during the recording of the album. McCluskey spoke of dissension between himself and the record company, whose "formula" demanded {{"'}}Whole Again', 'Whole Again' and more fucking 'Whole Again{{'"}}; he was essentially dismissed and legally prohibited from contacting the band,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandpopmusic/10055765/OMDs-Andy-McCluskey-Kerry-Katona-had-Marilyn-Monroe-syndrome.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220112/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandpopmusic/10055765/OMDs-Andy-McCluskey-Kerry-Katona-had-Marilyn-Monroe-syndrome.html |archive-date=12 January 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live|title=OMD's Andy McCluskey: Kerry Katona had Marilyn Monroe syndrome|last=McCormick|first=Neil|date=14 May 2013|website=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|access-date=17 September 2017}}{{cbignore}}</ref> before exiting the "very dirty" business of "manufactured pop".<ref name="bbcbreakfast"/> Released tracks from ''Feels So Good'' were "[[It's OK! (Atomic Kitten song)|It's OK]]", "[[The Tide Is High (Get the Feeling)]]", "[[The Last Goodbye (Atomic Kitten song)|The Last Goodbye]]","[[Love Doesn't Have to Hurt]]", and "[[Be with You (Atomic Kitten song)|Be With You]]". The title track was written by [[Kylie Minogue]]. "The Last Goodbye" was the 3rd single from their second studio album, ''Feels So Good'' and "Be With You" was from their third album, ''[[Ladies Night (Atomic Kitten album)|Ladies Night]]''.

The first single, "It's OK", peaked at number three in the United Kingdom. The next single was "The Tide Is High (Get the Feeling)", a remake of the 1967 song by [[The Paragons]] that [[Blondie (band)|Blondie]] covered in 1980, which gave the group their third number-one single in the UK and New Zealand.<ref name=uk/><ref name="nz"/> In April 2002 Hamilton announced that she was pregnant but opted to continue with the promotion before going on maternity leave, which included the scheduled 2002 tour, the "Tide is High (Get the Feeling)" video, and a "Feels So Good" medley at [[Party in the Park]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.funtrivia.com/en/Music/Atomic-Kitten-7675.html|title=Fun Trivia: Atomic Kitten|access-date=20 December 2018}}</ref> The band sponsored a team in the [[British Touring Car Championship]].

During January and February 2003, Atomic Kitten toured Southeast Asia, visiting Singapore, Thailand, and Korea. Hamilton, who had given birth to her son Josh on 24 August 2002, brought him on the tour.<ref>[http://www.lewscomputers.co.uk/atomickittenactive/arc0103.htm Atomic Kitten active – News 9 January 2003] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070210200642/http://www.lewscomputers.co.uk/atomickittenactive/arc0103.htm |date=10 February 2007 }}. Retrieved 30 July 2006</ref>

===2003–2008: ''Ladies Night'', ''Greatest Hits'' and hiatus===
In April 2003, the album ''[[Atomic Kitten (album)|Atomic Kitten]]'' was released in the United States, which consisted of tracks from their first two albums. The album was unsuccessful, although "The Tide Is High (Get the Feeling)" appeared on the soundtrack for the feature film, ''[[The Lizzie McGuire Movie]]''. Following this, the group opted to focus solely on the European, Oceanian, South African and Asian markets.<ref name="Arkansas">[http://www.thetraveleronline.com/media/storage/paper688/news/2004/10/01/Lifestyles/Atomic.Kitten.What.America.Is.Missing-738247.shtml?norewrite200608161517&sourcedomain=www.thetraveleronline.com The Arkansas Traveler online: Atomic Kitten: what America is missing]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Retrieved 16 August 2006</ref>

Before recording their third album, [[Kool & the Gang]] approached the group about a collaboration for their album of duets, ''The Hits: Reloaded''. Kool & the Gang wanted to record an updated version of their hit "[[Ladies' Night (song)|Ladies Night]]" and were looking for a girl group to sing the lyrics. Atomic Kitten liked the idea and inquired whether they could use it for their next album which was subsequently named ''[[Ladies Night (Atomic Kitten album)|Ladies Night]]'' in honour of this collaboration.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/cbbcnews/hi/uk/newsid_3223000/3223341.stm|title=Ladies Night interview|publisher=CBBC News|access-date=29 July 2006}}</ref> After mainly relying on songwriters for their previous two albums, the group took significant creative control, co-writing eight of the fifteen songs. ''Ladies Night'' was released on 10 November 2003 and peaked at number five in the UK album chart. It was certified Platinum for sales in excess of 300,000 copies.<ref name=uk/><ref name=bpi/> The album included four UK top 10 singles; "Be With You", "Ladies Night", "If You Come To Me" and "[[Someone like Me]]".

In March 2004, the group released the double A-side single "Someone like Me"/"Right Now 2004", and embarked on their Greatest Hits Tour to support the ''Ladies Night'' album and the upcoming release of their ''[[Greatest Hits (Atomic Kitten album)|Greatest Hits]]'' album. Shortly before the tour began, the group announced they would be taking an extended break after the completion of the tour, which would serve as a "goodbye" to their fans.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/cbbcnews/hi/music/newsid_2551000/2551591.stm|title=Atomic Kitten reveal new tour dates|publisher=CBBC News|access-date=30 July 2006}}</ref> The tour's final concert was released on DVD under the title ''[[The Greatest Hits Live at Wembley Arena]]'' on 19 April 2004. During the group's 2012 reunion in ''[[The Big Reunion]]'', Hamilton revealed that she had decided to quit the group under the pressure of being a new mum and touring, having only been diagnosed with [[postpartum depression|postnatal depression]] only nine months after she gave birth. This later led to the group splitting because they did not want to replace Hamilton.

On [[Valentine's Day]] 2005, a partially re-recorded version of "[[Cradle (Atomic Kitten song)|Cradle]]" from their debut album ''Right Now'' with new vocals from McClarnon and Frost, titled "Cradle 2005", was released as a charity single, with proceeds going to [[World Vision]].<ref>[http://www.atomickittenz.com/home.php?pid=1 AtomicKittenz] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050316025539/http://www.atomickittenz.com/home.php?pid=1 |date=16 March 2005 }}. Retrieved 31 December 2005</ref> It was later included on a remix compilation titled ''Access All Areas: Remixed & B-Sides'', which was released in Asia in July that year packaged with the Greatest Hits Live DVD. In 2005, the group were featured on the soundtrack of Disney's ''[[Mulan II]]'' with the song "(I Wanna Be) Like Other Girls". They also performed together in [[Kraków]] on 28 August at the [[Coca-Cola]] SoundWave Festival.<ref>{{cite web|last=Nissim|first=Mayer|date=16 March 2011|title=Kerry Katona 'wants Atomic Kitten reunion'|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/music/a309275/kerry-katona-wants-atomic-kitten-reunion/|access-date=1 May 2012|website=Digital Spy|language=en-GB}}</ref> In 2006, they released a cover version of [[The Farm (British band)|The Farm]] song "[[All Together Now (The Farm song)|All Together Now]]". It became a charity single for the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] and was released only in German-speaking countries. It peaked inside the German Top 20. The group performed at The Nokia New Year's Eve Music Festival in [[Hong Kong]] on 31 December 2006.

They once again reunited to perform at The Number One Project at the [[Liverpool Echo Arena]] on 19 January 2008, which celebrated Liverpool's year as [[European Capital of Culture]] and the fact that Liverpudlian artists have had a collective 56 UK number-one singles. Also to mark the event, in the same month the group released a cover of "[[Anyone Who Had a Heart (song)|Anyone Who Had a Heart]]", which peaked at number 78 on the UK Singles Chart.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://popdirt.com/atomic-kitten-reunite-for-liverpools-the-number-one-live-concert/66276/|title=Atomic Kitten Reunite For Liverpool's The Number One Live Concert|publisher=popdirt.com|date=29 December 2007|access-date=20 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Jones |first=Catherine |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/liz-mcclarnon-coleen-nolan-star-3339683 |title=Liz McClarnon and Coleen Nolan star in Cinderella at the Liverpool Empire this Christmas |publisher=Liverpool Echo |date=13 July 2012 |access-date=4 June 2014}}</ref> The group also performed at the Kings Lynn Festival on 12 July 2008 and at Haydock Park in Liverpool on 19 July 2008.

===2012–2013: Return and ''The Big Reunion''===
[[File:Atomic Kitten (cropped version).jpg|thumb|right|Atomic Kitten in 2013]]
In March 2012, Hamilton confirmed that the group were reuniting for a summer tour and were in talks to star in their own reality television show regarding the comeback, following on the success of the 2011 [[Steps (group)|Steps]] reunion and reality show.<ref name="Reunion?">{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a369236/atomic-kitten-reunion-confirmed-by-natasha-hamilton.html|title=Atomic Kitten reunion confirmed by Natasha Hamilton|last=Daniels|first=Colin|date=4 March 2012|work=[[Digital Spy]]|access-date=1 May 2012}}</ref> She also said that she hoped Katona would join her, McClarnon and Frost on stage for a performance, having quit the group 11 years earlier. The reunion was later dismissed by all members due to the tension between Katona and Frost.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Eames|first=Tom|date=3 April 2012|title=Atomic Kitten's Frost, Katona in feud?|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/music/a374550/atomic-kitten-reunion-halted-by-jenny-frost-kerry-katona-feud/|access-date=7 July 2021|website=Digital Spy|language=en-GB}}</ref> However, on 18 October 2012, it was announced that the 1999 line-up of Atomic Kitten (McClarnon, Katona, and Hamilton) would reunite for an [[ITV2]] series, ''[[The Big Reunion]]'', along with five other pop groups of their time: [[911 (English group)|911]], [[Honeyz]], [[B*Witched]], [[Five (group)|Five]] and [[Liberty X]].<ref name="The Big Reunion">{{cite news|url=http://www.gigwise.com/news/77094/the-90s-are-back-reunions-from-atomic-kitten-5ive-and-more|title=The 90s are back: reunions from Atomic Kitten, 5ive, and more|work=Gigwise|date=18 October 2012}}</ref> Frost had been involved in the early meetings to reform the group, but declined to rejoin due to her pregnancy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2013-01-29/the-big-reunion-atomic-kitten-on-their-plans-to-remain-whole-again|title=Atomic Kitten on Staying Whole Again|work=[[Radio Times]]|date=29 January 2013}}</ref> In 2015, she expressed dissatisfaction with how the reunion was handled, which left her estranged from both Hamilton and McClarnon.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://closeronline.co.uk/celebrity/news/jenny-frost-dont-speak-atomic-kitten-didnt-like-things-kerry-katona-handled/ | title=Jenny Frost: "I don't speak to Atomic Kitten – I didn't like how things with Kerry Katona were handled" }}</ref>

The groups in ''The Big Reunion'', including Atomic Kitten, were originally supposed to perform a one-off comeback concert at the [[Hammersmith Apollo]] in London.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a455929/big-reunion-uk-arena-tour-in-the-works.html|title='Big Reunion' UK arena tour in the works|last=Daniels|first=Colin|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines UK]]|date=3 February 2013|access-date=11 February 2013}}</ref> Atomic Kitten's setlist for the Hammersmith Apollo concert consisted of "[[Right Now (Atomic Kitten song)|Right Now]]", "[[The Tide Is High (Get the Feeling)]]", and "[[Whole Again]]". It was confirmed on 11 February that due to high ticket demands and the popularity of the series, [[The Big Reunion (concerts)|a UK arena tour]] would take place from 3 to 14 May 2013.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a457835/5ive-atomic-kitten-bwitched-liberty-x-911-for-big-reunion-arena-tour.html|title=5ive, Atomic Kitten, B*Witched, Liberty X, 911 for Big Reunion arena tour|last=Nissam|first=Mayer|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines|Hearst Magazines UK]]|date=11 February 2013|access-date=11 February 2013}}</ref> Two more dates were later added for 16 and 17 May, taking the tour total to 14 shows.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.goldenplec.com/66192|title=The Big Re-Union announces show at The O2 and Odyssey Arena|publisher=Goldenplec|date=14 February 2013|access-date=14 February 2013}}/</ref>

Due to the massive success of ''The Big Reunion'', it was announced that the reunited groups would also be going on a "Christmas party tour" in December 2013.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a468755/5ive-bwitched-atomic-kitten-for-big-reunion-christmas-party-tour.html|title=5ive, B*Witched, Atomic Kitten for 'Big Reunion' Christmas Party tour|date=27 March 2013|work=[[Digital Spy]]|access-date=30 March 2013}}</ref> In December 2013, Atomic Kitten recorded their first new material in ten years when, along with the other groups from the show, they recorded a Christmas charity single for ''[[Text Santa]]'', a cover of [[Wizzard]]'s "[[I Wish It Could Be Christmas Everyday]]". The song peaked at number 13 in the UK.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/x-factors-sam-bailey-crowned-2013-official-christmas-number-1-2693/|title=X Factor's Sam Bailey crowned 2013 Official Christmas Number 1|last=Lane|first=Daniel|date=22 November 2013|publisher=[[Official Charts Company]]|access-date=16 November 2014}}</ref>

===2013–2019: Touring and Katona's second departure===
On 17 February 2013, Atomic Kitten made an appearance on ''[[The Alan Titchmarsh Show]]'' in which Katona announced that the group had signed a deal to release their own perfume fragrance. Hamilton later added that they would be releasing new material, saying: "We've already been in the studio, we want to write some more music, so it's all very exciting."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/showbiz/news/a459425/atomic-kitten-land-perfume-range-deal-writing-new-material.html|title=New Atomic Kitten Material|work=[[Digital Spy]]|date=17 February 2013}}</ref> On 14 March, Hamilton confirmed yet again that the group would release new material, saying "There is definitely going to be a single and there will be an album, hopefully". Also speaking about their fragrance deal, she added: 'We have got a perfume deal - we are going to be releasing our own Atomic Kitten fragrance. "Right Now", "The Tide Is High" and "Whole Again" are taken from ''The Big Reunion Album''. It's going to be three different smells to represent the three of us. Fans will get the three in one packet. We went to the company's offices and created our fragrances.'<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/showbiz/news/a465563/atomic-kitten-to-launch-new-fragrance-with-three-different-scents.html|title=Atomic Kitten to launch new fragrance with three different scents|date=14 March 2013|work=[[Digital Spy]]|access-date=14 March 2013}}</ref> At the Health Lottery champagne tea at [[Claridge's]] in London, Hamilton spoke of a potential comeback single: "We actually recorded our new single last night. We've literally just done it. I got out of the studio at 11 pm and I couldn't stop singing the song. I couldn't get to sleep - I was in bed, singing! It's modern so we've progressed. That's all I can say right now. If there's a single, there's definitely going to be an album."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/music/new-atomic-kitten-music-on-way-29162859.html|title=New Atomic Kitten music on way|work=[[Irish Independent]]|date=29 March 2013|access-date=30 March 2013}}</ref>

Following the announcement of Katona's pregnancy, the group confirmed that they were unsure of the group's future, or if any new material would be released. McClarnon announced on 6 April that Atomic Kitten would be touring with [[East 17]] and [[All Saints (group)|All Saints]] and others in November 2014. The next week it was announced that unforeseen circumstances had cancelled the tour.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/news/all-saints/76826|title=NME News: All Saints, East 17, Atomic Kitten tour cancelled|date=20 April 2014|work=[[NME]]|access-date=16 November 2014}}</ref>

In November 2014, Katona said the group would release a new album in 2015, which would go back to their original "cheesy pop sound" and tour it "around the world".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a609856/atomic-kitten-to-release-new-music-in-2015-says-kerry-katona.html|title=Atomic Kitten to release new music in 2015, says Kerry Katona|last=Eames|first=Tom|date=16 November 2014|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines UK]]|access-date=16 November 2014}}</ref> The group's planned '15: The Greatest Hits' tour was canceled in mid-May 2015 with no announcement as to why. In November 2015, the group released a compilation album entitled ''Whole Again – The Best of Atomic Kitten''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Whole-Again-Best-Atomic-Kitten/dp/B015NSUUX0/ref=sr_1_5?ie=UTF8&qid=1446020884&sr=8-5&keywords=atomic+kitten |title=Whole Again - The Best of Atomic Kitten by Atomic Kitten: Amazon.co.uk: Music |website=Amazon.co.uk |access-date=14 January 2016}}</ref>

In late 2016, [[Liberty X]]'s [[Michelle Heaton]] filled in for McClarnon during the group's international gigs as McClarnon has a debilitating fear of flying.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n1dF-N644p0| archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211117/n1dF-N644p0| archive-date=2021-11-17 | url-status=live|title=Michelle Heaton on Joining Atomic Kitten And Acting - Loose Women|last=Loose Women|date=16 August 2016|via=YouTube}}{{cbignore}}</ref>

On 12 November 2016, Katona, Hamilton, and McClarnon performed at the Pigs Nose Inn, a small live music venue in [[South Devon]] known for attracting high-profile acts. Atomic Kitten chose to perform a prelude to their tour in 2017.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/blur-atomic-kitten-local-pub-gets-all-the-best-gigs-h3l8hszm0|title=Blur, Atomic Kitten: local pub gets all the best gigs|work=The Times|last1=Narwan |first1=Gurpreet }}</ref> Atomic Kitten toured Australia and New Zealand alongside [[B*Witched]], [[S Club]] 3, [[East 17]] and [[Liberty X]] in February 2017 with Heaton once again filling in for McClarnon.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/newslocal/mosman-daily/michelle-heaton-gets-pulses-racing-with-both-liberty-x-and-atomic-kitten-on-the-bwitched-tour/news-story/fd995c3761371e99182d049d09779b06|title=Heaton's fresh double act|date=5 February 2017|website=www.dailytelegraph.com.au|access-date=20 December 2018}}</ref>

In November 2017, Katona stated on her social media accounts that she was no longer a part of the group.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/kerry-katona-booted-out-atomic-11546963|title=Kerry Katona 'booted out of Atomic Kitten after insulting Natasha Hamilton'|first=Emmeline|last=Saunders|date=18 November 2017|website=Daily Mirror|access-date=20 December 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/showbiz/a852273/atomic-kitten-natasha-hamilton-explains-feud-kerry-katona/|title=Atomic Kitten's Natasha explains feud with Kerry Katona|first=Sam|last=Warner|date=14 March 2018|website=Digital Spy|access-date=20 December 2018}}</ref> Hamilton and McClarnon continued to perform as a duo.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/footballs-coming-home-again-watch-atomic-kitten-sing-reworked-hit-for-england-fans-2984508|title="Football's coming home again": watch Atomic Kitten sing reworked hit for England fans|last=Neale|first=Matthew|date=4 July 2021|work=[[NME]]|access-date=7 July 2021}}</ref>

===2020–present: Frost's return ===
In June 2020, Frost joined Hamilton and McClarnon for an online interview as part of "Life Stories – The Interview Series" hosted by [[therapist]] Lisa Johnson and Hamilton herself. The band discussed their time together and the impact being in a girl band had on their individual [[mental health]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.instagram.com/p/CBN0CIQpchX/ | title=Natasha Gay on Instagram: "So that's it a only 1 day left until 'Life Stories - the Interview Series' kicks off!! . Eternally grateful for everyone who has got on board and supported my idea and helped turn it in to something special💖 . Follow the link in my bio & sign up for 'Life Stories' streaming Wednesday & Thursday in 'Live Better with Natasha' from 10am - 3pm 🙏🏼 X" }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.instagram.com/p/CBRPVfGpBrj/ | title=Jenny Frost on Instagram: "Was fab catching up with my Kittens today on Tash's Facebook page (Once I got my head around a technical hitch 🤦🏼‍♀️) and the 3 of us had a good old catch up after too & it was just lovely. We don't speak often enough but when we do it's like we've just spoken yesterday...so so funny. We've been through so much together & you'll always be my family,love you girls... @lizmcclarnon @natashahamilton XXX (& thank you @lisajohnsoncoaching 🙏🏽) x" }}</ref>

On 6 July 2021, the group released a remake of "Whole Again" in support of [[England national football team|England]] at [[UEFA Euro 2020]], entitled "Southgate You're the One (Football's Coming Home Again)". Frost returned to the band for the first time since 2008 for the single release.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/atomic-kitten-gareth-southgate-whole-again-b1879534.html?amp|title=Atomic Kitten fans react to Gareth Southgate remix 'Football's Coming Home Again'|last=O'Connor|first=Roisin|date=7 July 2021|website=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=7 July 2021}}</ref> They said: "It's been a whirlwind couple of days, but we are super excited and grateful to be able to contribute to the awesome energy and patriotism that is filling the England streets with this version of Whole Again. Totally inspired by the England football fans in support of [[Gareth Southgate]] and the super talented England football team, we will be singing loud and proud 'Football's coming home'."<ref>{{cite news|last=McCann|first=Jaymi|date=7 July 2021|title=Fans react after Atomic Kitten reunite to release England song 'Southgate You're the One'|url=https://inews.co.uk/news/uk/atomic-kitten-england-football-song-southgate-youre-the-one-whole-again-1090972|access-date=7 July 2021|website=i|language=en}}</ref>

On 29 November 2021, the group confirmed that Frost was returning to the group full time, adding that they would be supporting [[boy band]] [[Blue (English group)|Blue]] on their [[arena]] tour in September 2022.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://metro.co.uk/2021/11/30/atomic-kitten-are-reuniting-to-go-on-tour-with-blue-in-2022-15692035/|title=Atomic Kitten are reuniting to go on tour with Blue and suddenly it's 2001 again|website=Metro|last=Bashforth|first=Emily|date=30 November 2021}}</ref>
